title: Giving away your fortune
intro: Mark Zuckerberg, the creator of the social media platform Facebook, has announced he will give away most of his fortune. Neil and Sophie talk about robber barons, industrialization in America, and what it takes to be a modern-day philanthropist.
this_week_question: Who was the most generous philanthropist in the US in 2014? Was it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: helping others, especially by giving large amounts of money to good causes
people's ability to develop or achieve things
(in this context) a situation where all children are equal with the same rights and opportunities as each other

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: And I'm Sophie…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sophie, I can't get out of my head what Mark Zuckerberg, you know, the guy who created Facebook, said recently.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Oh, I know, he pledged – or made a serious promise – to give away 99% of his shares in Facebook over the course of his lifetime. The shares are currently worth around $45bn.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Why, oh why did he decide to give his fortune away? It's puzzling to me.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: It's an act of philanthropy – which means helping others, especially by giving large amounts of money to good causes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And philanthropy is the subject of this show.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: But don't worry about Zuckerberg, it's probably fair to say that he will remain extremely well off – or wealthy – even after giving away his fortune.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's true. Let me ask you then today's quiz question: Who was the most generous philanthropist in the US last year? Was it… a) Bill Gates b) Mark Zuckerberg Or c) Warren Buffett

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: I'm going to say… c) Warren Buffett.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if you were right or not later on in the show. Now, Zuckerberg was inspired to give away his fortune by the birth of his daughter Max. In a letter to Max – posted on Facebook. In his post, he talks about using the money to advance human potential and promote equality for all children in the next generation. Equality – in other words, with the same rights and opportunities.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Zuckerberg is the latest in a long line of billionaire entrepreneurs to turn philanthropist and use his money for good causes. Did you know that some of the earliest American philanthropists were robber barons?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Robber barons? What's … ? Hang on, what're robber barons?

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: They're business people who use unethical - or morally wrong - business tactics to gain large personal fortunes. Nineteenth-century entrepreneurs like Rockefeller, Carnegie and Ford were robber barons. They built up huge empires in industry – oil, steel, railways, and cars – and were largely responsible for transforming the United States from an agricultural nation into an industrial one.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Henry Ford – he's the one who said you can have any colour you want as long as it's black. I like that kind of thing.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Focus, Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. OK.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: But as the barons got older, they decided they wanted to give back to society, and turned to philanthropy. Andrew Carnegie believed that wealth should be spent to make the world a better place.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That sounds too warm and fuzzy for a ruthless – or cruel - robber baron.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: People change, Neil! When he died, Carnegie had given away a total of $350m to the state to spend on public works. That's around $8bn in today's money.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, let's listen to Hugh Cunningham, a Professor of History at the University of Kent here, in the UK. He talks about what the average Joe – that's you and me, folks – thinks about big business and philanthropy today.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Hugh Cunningham, Emeritus Professor of History at the University of Kent The very word philanthropy does not necessarily have 100% positive connotations for the public at large given where we are in terms of the public's attitude towards business or the banks and that kind of stuff. So I think it's in everyone's interests to try and broaden out the concept of philanthropy into a wider notion of giving, making a contribution, making a difference.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, banks and big businesses can easily afford to give away millions of dollars for the public good if they choose to. It is not so easy when you're an individual struggling to pay the rent.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: That's right, Neil. But a lot of people in the UK are super-rich compared to those in the developing world. And we can make a big difference by donating – or giving – smaller amounts of money to help improve their lives.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that's what Professor Cunningham means when he says we should broaden out the notion – or idea – of philanthropy. It's not only robber barons who can afford to be philanthropic. Let's listen to Toby Ord, a graduate student from Oxford University talking about how he makes a difference.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Toby Ord, moral philosopher, Oxford University I worked out that over my life I'd be able to earn about £1.5m and that I could maintain my current standard of living as a graduate student and still donate about £1m of that.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: So Toby actually gives away any money that he earns above £18,000 a year. He feels that he doesn't need more than this amount to maintain his standard of living.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm impressed by Toby's pledge but I don't think I could live like a student my whole life!

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: I thought that would suit you extremely well, Neil! Now why don't you give us the answer to today's quiz question?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I asked: Who was the most generous philanthropist in the US last year? Was it… a) Bill Gates? b) Mark Zuckerberg? Or c) Warren Buffett?

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: I said Warren Buffett.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good guess, Sophie! Well done! Buffett, who made his $73bn fortune from investments, donated $2.8bn to charity in 2014 bringing his lifetime total to almost $23bn, according to Forbes. That's a tidy sum – and that means a large number! OK let's hear those words again, Sophie.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Here they are: pledged philanthropy well off human potential equality unethical ruthless average Joe donating a tidy sum

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
